Opened issue "[Bug]: Upgrading a package across a large solution is downgraded when it should not have been" (#11777) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

vs 16.11.5

### Worked before?

Not really

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

We have 187 projects in our master solution and we publish several internal frameworks, as nuget packages, which these projects require. Also, there are several project dependencies between the various projects. Therefore, we need to upgrade everything all at once.

However, instead of having a clean upgrade process, we keep getting `Detected package downgrade` errors, regardless of which "Install and **Update** Options" we pick. And the note: 
```These options are not applicable to projects managing their dependencies through project.json or PackageReference```

This makes no sense since all of our projects use PackageReferences. So, when do these options apply then? 

Example of the error message, and thus the bug:
```
NU1605: Detected package downgrade: F from 9.5.4-b001-Debug to 9.5.4-a015-Debug. 
Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version. 
 A -> B -> C -> D -> E 9.5.4-b001-Debug -> F (>= 9.5.4-b001-Debug) 
 A -> B -> F (>= 9.5.4-a015-Debug)
```

First issue: the message "Reference the package directly from the **project** to select a different version." 

Which project? We have 187 of them. Therefore, this message should be changed to specify which project.

Main Issue:
1. The upgrade rules clearly state that `B` can use any version of `F` that is greater than or equal to `9.5.4-a015-Debug`
2. According to [semver 2.0](https://semver.org/#spec-item-11) sections 11.4.2 & 11.4.4, (assuming we have read the spec correctly) state that the version number `9.5.4-b*` is greater than `9.5.4-a*`.
3. Therefore, `F 9.5.4-b001-Debug` is greater than `F 9.5.4-a015-Debug` which satisfies the upgrade rule (see item 1 above.)

Thus this package should **not** be downgraded.

This behavior also suggests that the Nuget Manager is not following the solution's build dependencies, otherwise `B` would have been upgraded before `A` and this issue would not have existed in the first place.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: RestoreLockedMode fails when overriding reference from Directory.Builds.prop" (#11776) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

6.0.202

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Run `dotnet new console`
2. Replace the project file contents with the following

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>

    <RestoreLockedMode>true</RestoreLockedMode>
    <RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
    <DisableImplicitNuGetFallbackFolder>true</DisableImplicitNuGetFallbackFolder>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

3. Run `dotnet restore`
4. Note that `packages.lock.json` specifies version `6.0.0` of `Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection`
5. Create `Directory.Build.props` with the following contents

```xml
<Project>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection" Version="5.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

6. Run `dotnet restore`

EXPECTED: 

Operation completes successfully. `packages.lock.json` continues to use version of `6.0.0` of `Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection`

ACTUAL:

Receive error message: 

> C:\temp\RestoreIssue\RestoreIssue.csproj : error NU1004: The package reference Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection version has changed from [6.0.0, ) to [5.0.0, ).The packages lock file is inconsistent with the project dependencies so restore can't be run in locked mode. Disable the RestoreLockedMode MSBuild property or pass an explicit --force-evaluate option to run restore to update the lock file.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet project cache data not updated on package uninstall" (#5505) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I ran into this while looking into https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5503

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): VS2017

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.3.0.4199

VS version (if appropriate): d15prerel/26627

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. File new project, ProjA, Net standard class library. Change the framework to net standard 1.0. -> 

2. Add new project, ProjB, to solution i.e. Net framework class library. Ensure the target framework is net461 or higher.

3. Add reference to ProjB in ProjA.

4. Restore solution. No errors or warnings.

5. Add a package targeting net461 to ProjB.

6. Restore solution. Error in ProjA since ProjB targets a higher framework.

7. Uninstall package from ProjB.

8. Restore solution.

## Expected

Solution should restore , just as in step 4.

## Actual

Error in ProjA since ProjB targets a higher framework.



Seems that we do not update the NuGet cache on package uninstall.
[netstandard1.0.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1110448/netstandard1.0.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Enable data analytics for Include Prerelease" (#6588) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: We should enable data analytics on the include prerelease setting in VS.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet clients should warn if nuget.org is used as an HTTP source" (#7186) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Discussion started during discussing this PR - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/2379.

Currently nuget client does not warn users that use http instead of https. Adding a warning may help in moving people to https.

Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.DataAI.NuGetRecommender.Contracts, Version=2.1.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a' or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file specified.


On vs 2019  package manager works as expected even without NugetRecommender
